title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
I know this is a bit off topic, but human technology - ranging from genetic manipulation to artificial intelligence - is slowly approaching the point where it is conceivable that within this century humans could be capable of creating an entirely new life form. 
I'm not talking only clones or hybrids - which have already been achieved at various levels - but engineering a new living being from scratch by synthesizing DNA in the full "design" that one would desire. Outside of biological designs of this sort, the question also arises whether artificial intelligence could ever advance to the point that one would create a sentient electro-mechanical "living" being - where the question would also arise as to what constitutes "life". Any such technology is still quite far away but it does bring up interesting moral issues of humans dangerously "playing God". Already moral questions of human - animal hybrids or human clones have started to become relevant since the technology seems to be just around the corner. 
If anybody is interested in these issues, this forums seems as good a a place as any to discuss them. What are your thoughts - either on the morality behind human manipulation / creation of life or on the potential technology behind it?

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment: If you mean starting from scratch with absolutely no genetic material at all as part of the formula or equation, then I don't believe man will ever accomplish that. Only God can create new life from nothing, or from non life shall we say.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
Well, man might someday gain the capability of fully synthasizing a molecule as complex as DNA from scratch. Of course, he would use the knowledge gained from studying how various DNA codes affect natural biological characteristics in order to properly design that DNA to achieve the desired characteristics. It might be even more difficult to then take that synthesized DNA and put it in an egg and artificial womb that has no natural (as opposed to artificial) biological parts, but even that might be achievable someday through chemical construction. All this means is that humanity might someday be able to copy the methods of nature to create a new being - perhaps even use creativity to create beings of very different natural functions than we see in our world.
It is all interesting to think about and could well be achievable within this century. We already are capable of a large degree of genetic manipulation through cloning and hybridization. One would think that it will only be a matter of time before more complex technologies get developed.
The other question, of course, is - If we could someday create new life using our technology, should we? That would bring up a whole host of issues, including:
- Would we know what we were doing well enough not to cause great harm?
- How would the beings we create be treated?

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
Here is a strand of DNA: To think that Man can design, structure and then create such a thing that when fertilized and planted will actually grow into an independent life form with equal and functioning parts is a real stretch for me to even conceive as probable, much less possible. 
http://rds.yahoo.com/_ylt=A0WTb_0OcX...ca8%26ei=UTF-8
 There are approximately 60 trillion cells in the human body. Each of these cells carry material called chromosomes. Along those chromosomes are about 100,000 genes. The gene is what carries our heredity.
It determines everything from our eye and hair color to our risk for diseases like heart disease and diabetes. Inside each gene is Deoxyribonucleic Acid - DNA - whose purpose is to carry out a single function.
"DNA is a polymer,a molecule, made up of a large number of atoms, arranged in repeating units called nucleotides." ( Criminalistics, Saferstein, Richard, 2001) Nucleotides are then strung together to form thew DNA strand.
There are four bases attached to the backbone of the DNA strand: adenine, cytosine, guanine, thymine. The DNA strand can go on forever containing millions of bases.
Double Helix 
There are actually two DNA strands called a double Helix. They resemble two wires twisted around each other.
The two strands are connected by the four bases, adenine, cytosine, guanine, and thymine ( A,C,G,T).
The pairing of the bases has to go in a certain pattern. Although there can be different sequences, A must attach to T and G must attach to C:
A........T
G........C
C........G
A........T
T........A
C........G
This is called base pairing. Although this is the way the bases must be paired together, there is no limit on how the bases are sequenced on the strand. So there are limitless possibilities of sequencing.
Each strand of DNA has the same information. It's how the bases are sequenced that determines our unique genetic heredity, including any predisposition to certain diseases.
All the human chromosomes contain about three billion base pairs. This is referred to as the genetic code. An individualized code that is as unique to each of us as our fingerprints, except in the case of identical twins.
The complexity of sequencing more than 3 billion pairs of chromosomes in order to create a viable creature in the mammal family is so far beyond mans capabilities today, and will always be in my humble opinion.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
Fairly long pieces of DNA (oligonucleotides) are already fairly cheap and easily available. Several labs have accomplished the larger feat of synthesising entire viral genomes (polio and smallpox) from scratch. Microbial genomes are only a year or three away. This technology is virtually here.
Designing a totally novel organism from scratch, with completely unprecedented metabolic systems and enzymes, would be a much more difficult feat to accomplish, and I wouldn't anticipate that for decades yet. However, engineered organisms with wholly new functions and features aren't nearly as improbable. Genetically engineered organisms with minor modifications are already agriculturally, industrially and medically important; examples with more extensive modifications should be coming soon.
The problem with religious zealots is they keep themselves deliberately ignorant of science, which is why they rarely have a clue what it is or isn't capable of accomplishing. But they never miss a chance to tell scientists that they know better than scientists do.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
Just to clarify the intention of my opening post, it was meant to imply that, within this century, we might be capable of designing life from scratch - not just hybridization (essentially cutting and pasting of existing pieces of naturally made DNA) or cloning. However, this does not mean that it need be a complex life form such as a mammal or even, for that matter, a multi-celled organism. 
We would have to start from the very simple life forms - such as a microbe - and progress from there. Since carbon based biological lifeforms are what we are most familiar with, any new life form we create would essentially copy the methods of nature and use the knowledge of metabolisms and general organic functions that we already see in nature - just custom picked for our own design purposes. Demon38's excellent article does suggest that we are quite close to creating that first very simple life-form. The fact that it would not last long in the lab is a secondary issue - creating life is one thing, keeping it alive is another further step. 
Synthetic biology is a field that combines science and engineering in order to design and build ("synthesize") novel biological functions and systems. From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_biology :
The references relating to synthesizing DNA of microbe-level complexity do suggest that we are already at the begining of being able to custom design DNA for very simple organisms. At the impressive speed at which genetic science has progressed over the last decades and, given the amount of effort put into the general field, I have little doubt that genetic technology will continue to make great strides to produce even more complex organisms and fully viable synthetic life within the following decades. It will be an interesting process to watch but one which we also need to discuss with respect to issues of safety, social implications, etc.
Even at the level of the very simple synthetic organisms addressed by the field of synthetic biology, some of the concerns include (from the same web page):
As this general field progresses farther, even more ethical issues will come into play to discuss. Either way, it is a fasciniating field to discover, follow and discuss.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment: I'm not clear on the hybridization point. Clearly designing life utterly from scratch is well beyond our current means. Any life we create in the near future would be as similar to existing life as any given cell is to any other; things like structure, metabolic pathways, etc would all be pretty much the same. Given that, the simplest method for creating "new" life would be to take the genome of an existing organism, a bacteria for example, get rid of the genes we don't want, add the genes we do, and then synthesize it. I'm not talking about cutting and pasting genes into an existing strand of DNA, but rather using the information from an existing strand to design a new strand, and making that from scratch. Would that count as hybridization to you?

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
By hybridization, I mean combining naturally-made portions of DNA as opposed to synthesizing the DNA from scratch - without using natural DNA to make it. Basically, it is harder to make a DNA molecule from scratch without using pre-existing self-replicating natural DNA molecules as building blocks.
If, as you mention, you would make a new strand of DNA from scratch without using natural DNA to physically make it , then I would not call that hybridization. However, just because you don't use natural DNA to make the synthetic DNA doesn't mean you wouldn't use the same types of designs that nature uses in existing DNA. I would think that using design knowledge gained from studying existing DNA would be necessary for the first range of life-forms. As an analogy, if you put together a car from various parts of other cars, then you have not made a car from scratch. You would have to make all the car parts separately anew to say that you have created an entirely new car. However, you are obviously going to learn how to design a car by looking at existing cars so, from that point of view, you are using information from the other cars - just not any physical parts from them. Of course, car parts do not self replicate so this is not a perfect analogy. 
The bottom line is that it is more impressive if you make new DNA from scratch without using any existing DNA than if you only cut and paste self-replicated pieces of existing DNA. It is just harder to claim that one created new life from scratch if one used existing life to make it. That is why I don't view hybridization as highly as I would synthesizing DNA molecules from scratch - which the wikipedia site seemed to refer to as do novo DNA synthesis.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
Designing and building a DNA molocule from scratch, based on knowledge from an existing DNA molecule, is within our grasp; we pretty much have the technology. However, we would still need to insert that DNA into a viable cell in order to have life. Life is more than just DNA after all, it's DNA ineracting with other systems in a cell. When we can bypass that step, and create life without having to use any components that were once living, that will be impressive!
As for the ethical concerns, I'm not too worried. In my life time I don't see us being likely to move beyond the single cell stage. We wouldn't be able to create life of a "high enough order" that I would worry about its rights or anything like that. Of course the technology could be misused, but that's true about many technologies. It should be used to help and not to harm, that's true of anything, and so I have no special concerns here.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
What has been spoken in this thread is a synthetic replica of life as we know it. That's hard, because the long periods of evolution have made things somewhat too complex.
However, creating A life would be different. All we'd need would be something capable of replicating itself from the environment. These could be much much more simple, and I do believe nanobots would be an example of this sort of life.
This would be much closer to our current reach.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
I completely agree. We wouldn't be able to claim that we truly had created new life until our technology would become independent from using natural life in the creation process. That would be quite an impressive feat but seems farther away. Nevertheless, Demon38's article did note efforts at synthetically creating cell membranes - that is at least a start. Being a physicist, not a biologist, I don't have a good feel for all of the other cell components that would be necessary to make a functioning, surviving, replicating cell, but it seems that the process to develop such parts are under way.
I'm afraid that I am not as optimistic as you seem to be. As I quoted in a previous post, there is a lot of potential damage that can be done if harmful pathogens are either accidentally or purposely created. That already is a large risk for us to take and, unlike the other main technological risk of nuclear weapons, such pathogens could well be easier and cheaper to make and, since they are replicating, their destructive power could be harder to control. 
As for higher level life forms, I agree that it would take quite a while - beyond our lifetimes - for us to produce a high enough level being whose rights we would need to address. At least that is true in the biological domain - artificial life-forms and artificial intelligence being another issue.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
Well, they would be cheap for a government to make, but almost impossible for your average terrorist. Making a viable new life form is a lot harder than making a nuke. But I can see the problem if a rouge nation wanted an easy to deploy weapon of mass destruction. It's much easy to sneak a test tube into a city than it is to launch a missle.
I guess when it comes to issues like this I tend to take the pragmatic approach. If a technology can be developed, it almost certainly will, by someone eventually. If "we" can do it now, anyone will probably be able to within our life times, regardless of whether or not we move ahead with our research. Our inaction would only delay things, not halt them. Given the huge benefits possible from this line of research I wouldn't halt it just because someone could misuse it. And there's also the point that if someone wanted a biological weapon, it would be much easier at this point to use an existing pathogen, rather than creating a new one from scratch. Nature has millions of years of experience at creating germs that kill people, I doubt we'll be that good for some while yet. But, as you noted, I do tend towards optimism. :)
Yes, non-biological life froms would be an entirely different kettle of fish.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
As a point of information, two artificial viruses have been constructed from scratch, i.e., they did not use existing strands of nucleic acid. These viruses were built by connecting the nucleotides (bases, sugar and phosphate) in the desired order. They began with the desired sequence and arranged the bases in that sequence. One of these viruses was poliovirus. Although it can't be tested, it is indistinguishable from the real thing. The other was a bacteriophage. It too is indistinguishable from the real thing and has been tested. It works just like the real thing, even to the point of reproducing itself when introduced into a bacterium, and then infecting nearby bacterium.
Of course, the poliovirus is an ssRNA virus so the sugar was ribose. I'm not sure about the bacteriophage since they can be can be DNA or RNA, both single and double stranded (ssDNA, dsDNA, ssRNA, dsRNA)?

Of course, in context, it is clear that Jefferson was talking about slavery, an institution that he claimed to oppose even though he never freed his own slaves. And, of course, Jefferson considered liberties to be self evident truths, not revealed in sacred writings. In fact, he rejected the idea of sacred writings, the Christian God, and the divinity of Christ.

Nobody made any such implication. Do I need to try typing slowly so that anybody with comprehension problems as bad as Archie's can follow?
There is no "Nobel Peace Prize in Science." Period. Anybody who pays attention to developments in science or who has a halfway decent science education would know this by virtue of being exposed to the findings of Nobel Prize winners. In my classes, we discuss the increases of our understanding of the world and specially recognize those scientists whose contributions were so great that they were awarded Nobel Prizes. Nobody has ever won a "Nobel Peace Prize in Science."
Likewise, nobody has ever won a "Nobel Prize in Science." There are Nobel Prizes awarded for certain scientific disciplines, but these are separate prizes. Only Archie is detached enough from reality to claim that the lack of a "Nobel Prize in Science" means that neither physics nor chemistry are sciences.
So showing that somebody is a complete idiot about a topic even though he claims to be informed enough to write a huge webpage full of quote mines and misrepresentations counts as "nitpicking"? That's like a murderer berating a judge for "nitpicking" after he's been convicted for homicide.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
I'm not completely sure if existing pathogens would be more dangerous than new ones. After all, we have evolved with the existing pathogens and are sufficiently imune to the great majority of them. The ones that are very lethal often, such as Ebola, tend to kill off the small group that gets exposed before they can spread the virus. Evolution would leave us completely unprepared for any completely new pathogen - a pathogen that is lethal but at a rate that also allows it to spread widely from a small sample. 
I agree that once the technology is developed or nearly developed, it is hard to control it completely. However, I bemoan the fact that there isn't more public discussion on the safety and societal issues surounding these new technologies - discussion that can spur government action at properly controlling the emergence or use of the genetic technology. Granted, many people who are unwilling or unable to educate themselves on the issues of genetic technology might take an all or nothing approach in wanting to ban it completely - so I would admit that pushing it into public debate might have its pitfalls. However, this is such an important advance in technology that having practically no public debates also seems dangerous. I was glad to hear that there are some people who try to push some of these issues into debate. For example, Stuart Newman tried to patent a human chimp hybrid in order to get the patent office to think about and address these issues. From http://www.wesleyjsmith.com/blog/200...ee-hybrid.html :
(On edit: The quoted blog got its information from this Washington Post site: http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn...2005Feb12.html )

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
On the other hand, evolution has given pathogens millions of years of practice in infecting humans, anything we develop from scratch wouldn't have that advantage. We'd have to rely on what we know about how infection works, and while we know a lot our knowledge is incomplete. Our best bet, I think, would be to take an existing pathogen and "enhance" it, either through direct genetic manipulation or through simple breeding. We can do this, and in fact have. In the name of "defensive research" both the U.S. and Russia have developed all sorts of super bugs; it will be decades before we could grow anything from scratch that could compete for lethality, or so I would guess.
Therein lies the rub. This is a complicated, scientific issue. Before you can have an intelligent opinion on the subject you need to educate yourself, and a distressingly small percentage of the populous is willing to do that. I'm all for public debate, but debate among the ignorant is pointless. It might benefit the scientific community to fund some educational endeavors. Travelling museum exhibits, TV documentaries, that sort of things. Until people have a basic understanding of the issues involved I don't see public debate being that beneficial.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
You make a good point that it may not be all that easy to make a virulent harmful pathogen from scratch since the process of infection may be complicated enought that it would take a while for us to understand it well enough to create an entirely new style of virus. Meanwhile, as you say, the military has developed a wide range of super-bugs. Hopefully, it has developed anti-viral drugs to combat the created pathogens so that, were some to be let loose, our ENTIRE species would not be decimated. These are the topics of occasional movies over recent years. I only hope that no group - terrorist or otherwise - gets it into their head to develop an uncontrollable virus. 
These are some of the reasons why I am always wary of the development of novel potentially vastly harmful technologies - it could be too easy to lose control of them. I am always impressed by the creativity behind new technologies but one cannot bound forward in scientific progress without occasionally stepping back and looking at the potential risks. After all, we are a far from perfect species, often very illogical, who are in some ways too "young" to possess some of these technologies. Very serious thought needs to be given as to how to control these technologies to absolutely reduce the risk of inadvertent (or purposeful) harm. 
My major concern is that, without public debate, real societal or safety issues may be cast asside by the power of the industries supporting the new technologies. Public debate does have its pitfalls but it also does highlight the points of potential danger and concern that might otherwise be overlooked in the rush toward technological development and profit. In the ideal world, I would love to have the public debate to clarify potential concerns about these technologies, and then have government panels of unbiased experts determine the paths of government involvement necessary to alleviate those concerns. Of course, that is the ideal world.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment: Here is another interesting article - "I am creating artificial life, declares US gene pioneer" (from the Guardian, dated October 6, 2007 ) - on the progress in creating a new artificial life. From http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/20....climatechange :

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
This reminds me about the debate over human cloning. Very broadly speaking, the ignorant were against it, the somewhat educated for it, and the well educated against it. At the low end people were worried about armies of clones, or clones grown just for their organs, or people acheiving immortatlity by leaving their estates to their clones. With a little education people found out how silly those concerns were and said "sure, why not?" With a bit more education you find out how many attempts it takes to make a viable clone, and how the failures often gave rise to birth defects, gigantism, or other problems. The birth defect issue was real and important, but you didn't hear about it much because most people were arguing about "organ banks" instead. 
I agree with your concerns, but I don't see any solution. Business will most likely do whatever makes them money, scientists will generally (though not always) do the research without worrying too much about how it can be misused, and the public (and by extenstion politicians) often can't be bothered to fully understand the issues involved. Public debate is quite likely to center around easy to grasp misconceptions rather than complicated realities. Your panel of unbiased experts sounds like a good plan, but even if they could be found in the end all they could do is advise the politicians, who would just as likely listen to the polls and lobbyists instead of the pros.
Ok, maybe I'm not always an optimist. :)

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment: A new article from BBC News shows that progress is continued to be made by Venter et al. on synthetic biology. This group had already produced synthetic DNA of a simple microbe. The next challenge was to insert that synthetic DNA into a living cell in order to have it function using that new DNA. The challenge apparently lay in having that new cell not reject foreign DNA. That trick has now been accomplished, though not yet with purely synthetic DNA. It is a stepping stone toward that goal. From BBC NEWS | Science & Environment | A step closer to 'synthetic life' :

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:

that is not going to happen today and in the future to come...

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
Since scientists are nearly there, I don't see how you can say that. Various groups, with Venter et al. seemingly in the lead, have made human-made DNA of a new simplified microbe. Once they get a new cell to accept and function with that foreign DNA, redefining that cell's identity as that new microbe, then humanity will have done it - the first new human technology-created life. 
In some ways, humanity has been creating new life for millenia with cross-breeding of species in agriculture and animal husbandry. However, such breading always was a matter of mixing and matching genes from existing species. With synthetic DNA, they could literally design the arbitrary features that they want, as long as they know how to construct the DNA sequence to generate such features. It is truly designed artificial life. The only thing left to make it completely human-made would be to put that DNA into a synthetically made cell instead of a real one, but that is farther in the future.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment: Very interesting. It seems researchers will get there soon.

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment: The leading research group in the world working on synthetic life has had a great breakthrough. As outlined in the BBC article - BBC News - 'Artificial life' breakthrough announced by scientists - Dr Craig Venter and his colleagues have created a bacterial cell that is the first life form to be entirely controlled by synthetic DNA. These particular cells are just copies of existing or "wild type" bacteria and the synthetic DNA is not being inserted into synthetic cells but replacing the natural DNA of natural cells. However, this research shows that making a living cell with a synthetic chromosome is possible - a major step towards purely synthetic life and highly significant in its own right. The researchers hope to use this technology to design new bacteria from scratch - cells that could carry out useful functions. However, there are potential risks...

title: When will human technology allow for creation of entirely new life?
comment:
So does this mean that we can make changes to a genome base pair at a time? If so, imagine the potential we have in creating a cell or even an embryo to do whatever we want it to. Once we reach a point that we can "print" whatever sequence we want and at whatever size we want, it would just be a matter of designing the life form we want and then growing it. It's not hard to imagine overcoming the next hurdle of programming computers to simulate this growth and then through an iterative process, just like evolution, coming up with designs. 
The potential risk of this seems huge plus the added problem of bio-weapons that could be developed once this becomes easy. Seems like yet another way for us to destroy ourselves.
